importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The start date of the previous longest government shutdown, which lasted 35 days and ended on January 25, 2019.
The end date of the previous longest government shutdown, marking the conclusion of a 35-day closure that was the longest in nearly 50 years.
The date of the article's update, indicating the current government shutdown is ongoing as of this point in time.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The duration of the 35-day shutdown in 2018, which was the longest in history and set a benchmark for future shutdowns.
The current full government shutdown has not yet been resolved, with no passage of the 12 required appropriations bills, indicating prolonged federal funding failure.

keyTakeAways: The last government shutdown, which began on December 22, 2018, lasted 35 days and was the longest in nearly 50 years.
This shutdown cost the U.S. an estimated $3 billion in lost GDP, according to the Congressional Budget Office.
During the 2018 shutdown, about 800,000 federal employees were affected, with approximately 300,000 furloughed and 500,000 exempted but unpaid.
A full government shutdown is currently ongoing as of October 21, 2025, due to Congress failing to pass any of the 12 appropriations bills needed to fund the federal government.
The current shutdown differs from the 2018 one because it is a full shutdown, not a partial one, meaning all federal agencies are halted without funding.
Partisan gridlock in Congress, including a narrow House majority and lack of 60 votes to end a Senate filibuster, has made legislative compromise difficult.
Government shutdowns have become less frequent since 1990, with only six occurring since that time, but political polarization has extended their duration.

namedEntities.name: United States federal government
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The central government of the U.S. responsible for national operations and funding
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The entity is central to the narrative of government shutdowns, as the article details periods when it has been closed due to lack of funding.

namedEntities.name: Congressional Budget Office (CBO)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A nonpartisan agency that provides economic and budgetary analysis to Congress
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The CBO estimated the economic cost of the 2018 shutdown at $3 billion, providing data to illustrate the financial impact of government shutdowns.

namedEntities.name: December 22, 2018
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The start date of the previous longest government shutdown
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It marks the beginning of a 35-day shutdown, which was the longest in history and a key reference point for comparing current events.

namedEntities.name: January 25, 2019
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The end date of the previous longest government shutdown
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It marks the end of a 35-day shutdown and serves as a benchmark for historical significance and duration.

namedEntities.name: Gillian Roberts and Kaanita Iyer
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Journalists reporting on the article for CNN
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: They are the authors of the article, providing credibility and context through reporting on recent government shutdowns.

namedEntities.name: CNN
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A major news network that published the article
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: CNN is a primary source of news for the public, making this article accessible and widely distributed to inform the public about the shutdown.

namedEntities.name: Republican Speaker Mike Johnson
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The Speaker of the U.S. House of Representatives representing the Republican Party
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He oversees a narrow House majority, contributing to the difficulty of passing funding legislation and maintaining a path to resolution.

namedEntities.name: Senate filibuster
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A procedural rule in the U.S. Senate allowing extended debate to block legislation
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The GOP lacks 60 votes to overcome a filibuster, which hinders bipartisan compromise and leads to prolonged shutdowns.

namedEntities.name: 12 appropriations bills
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Legislation required to fund different federal departments and agencies
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: No passage of these bills has occurred, resulting in the current full government shutdown.

namedEntities.name: 800,000 federal employees
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The workforce affected during the 2018 shutdown
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The scale of employee impact highlights the human and economic consequences of government shutdowns.

namedEntities.name: 300,000 furloughed employees
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Federal workers who were not paid and instructed not to report to work during the 2018 shutdown
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Demonstrates the direct impact on workers, including loss of income and job disruption.

namedEntities.name: 300,000 exempted employees
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Federal workers who were required to report to work but not paid during the 2018 shutdown
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Highlights a structural issue in federal operations during funding lapses.

namedEntities.name: partial shutdown (2018)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A shutdown where only certain agencies operated under funding approval
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Contrasts with the current full shutdown and illustrates a difference in scope and severity.

namedEntities.name: full government shutdown (current)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A shutdown where no federal agencies are funded and all operations cease
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The current situation represents a more severe and widespread disruption than the 2018 partial shutdown.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The U.S. federal government is currently in a full shutdown due to Congress failing to pass any of the 12 required appropriations bills. This follows a previous 35-day shutdown in 2018, which was the longest in nearly 50 years and cost the economy an estimated $3 billion in lost GDP. During the 2018 event, about 800,000 federal employees were affected, with 300,000 furloughed and 500,000 exempted. The current shutdown is more severe because it affects all federal agencies, unlike the 2018 partial shutdown. Political gridlock, including a narrow Republican majority and a lack of votes to end Senate filibusters, has made bipartisan agreement difficult. CNN reports on the ongoing situation and details which services are affected or continuing.
title: The last government shutdown was the longest in nearly 50 years. Here are all the recent shutdowns in one chart
